The document is the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992. It contains various sections and chapters related to the establishment, management, powers, and functions of the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI). The Act also includes provisions for the transfer of assets and liabilities from the existing Securities and Exchange Board to the new Board. It covers topics such as registration, finance, accounts and audit, penalties and adjudication, establishment of Securities Appellate Tribunals, and miscellaneous provisions. The Act defines key terms and provides rules and regulations for the securities market in India.

The provided information is from page 9 to page 14 of the "Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992.pdf" file. 

Page 9 includes information about the powers of the Board, such as summoning and examining individuals on oath, inspecting books and documents, issuing commissions for examination of witnesses or documents, and taking measures in the interests of investors or securities market.

Page 10 mentions the Board's power to regulate or prohibit the issue of prospectus, offer document, or advertisement soliciting money for the issue of securities.

Page 11 discusses the definition of a collective investment scheme and the power of the Board to issue directions and levy penalties.

Page 12 provides details about the Investigating Authority's powers, including the seizure and custody of books, registers, and other documents, examination of individuals on oath, and consequences for non-compliance.

Page 13 mentions the return of seized books and documents, the requirements for search and seizure, cease and desist proceedings, and the registration of venture capital funds and collective investment schemes.

Page 14 includes information about the registration of alternative investment funds and business trusts, and the definition of a collective investment scheme or mutual fund.

The provided information is from the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992.pdf. It includes various sections and amendments to the act. 

On page 14, there are several insertions made by different acts, including Act 13 of 2021, Act 26 of 2010, and Act 59 of 2002. The word "and" was omitted by Act 9 of 1995, and clause (aa) was omitted by Act 59 of 2002.

On page 15, it is mentioned that the Board receives sums from other sources as decided by the Central Government. The funds are used for salaries, allowances, and other expenses of the Board, as well as expenses authorized by the Act. The Board is required to maintain proper accounts and prepare an annual statement of accounts. The accounts are audited by the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India.

On page 16, there are penalties mentioned for various failures and defaults. These penalties range from not less than one lakh rupees to one crore rupees, depending on the nature of the failure or default.

On page 17, there are penalties mentioned for failure to redress investors' grievances, defaults in case of mutual funds, and penalties for fraudulent and unfair trade practices. The penalties range from not less than one lakh rupees to twenty-five crore rupees or three times the amount of profits made out of such practices.

On page 18, there are penalties mentioned for non-disclosure of acquisition of shares and takeovers, as well as penalties for contravention where no separate penalty has been provided.

On page 19, the power to adjudicate is mentioned. The Board can appoint an adjudicating officer to hold an inquiry and impose penalties for non-compliance with the specified sections of the Act.

Overall, the information provided includes details about amendments, sources of funds, penalties for various failures and defaults, and the power to adjudicate.

Page 26 states that the Board has the power to delegate its powers and functions to members, officers, or other individuals, subject to specified conditions. 

Page 27 mentions that any person aggrieved by an order of the Board or the rules and regulations made under this Act can appeal to the Central Government within a prescribed time period. No appeal will be admitted after the prescribed period, unless the appellant can prove sufficient cause for the delay. The appeal must be made in a specified form and accompanied by a copy of the order appealed against and the prescribed fees. The procedure for disposing of an appeal will be prescribed, and the appellant must be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard. 

Page 27 also includes a provision (20A) that states no order passed by the Board or the adjudicating officer under this Act is appealable, except as provided in section 15T or section 20. No civil court has jurisdiction over any matter that the Board or the adjudicating officer is empowered to pass an order on, and no injunction can be granted by any court or authority in relation to any action taken or to be taken in pursuance of an order passed by the Board or the adjudicating officer under this Act. 

Page 28 introduces the power of the Central Government to grant immunity to a person alleged to have violated the provisions of this Act or the rules and regulations made thereunder, subject to specified conditions. The immunity can be withdrawn if the person fails to comply with the conditions or gives false evidence. 

Page 29 mentions that the High Court can exercise the powers conferred by Chapters XXIX and XXX of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, on a High Court, as if a Special Court within the jurisdiction of the High Court were a Court of Session. It also states that the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, apply to proceedings before a Special Court, with necessary modifications. 

Page 29 further explains that any offence committed under this Act, which is triable by a Special Court, will be taken cognizance of and tried by a Court of Session until a Special Court is established. 

Page 29 provides an explanation of the terms "company" and "director" for the purposes of this Act. 

Page 30 mentions the power of the Recovery Officer to recover amounts due from a person who fails to pay penalties, comply with directions of the Board, or pay fees. The modes of recovery include attachment and sale of movable and immovable property, attachment of bank accounts, arrest and detention, and appointment of a receiver. 

Page 30 also includes provisions regarding the liability of legal representatives to pay sums due from a deceased person and the limitations on their liability. 

Page 31 states that the powers of the Board under this Act do not apply to an International

This document is a section of the Securities and Exchange Board of India Act, 1992. It includes information about the procedures and regulations related to the Board's meetings, the terms and conditions of service for officers and employees, matters relating to the issue of capital and transfer of securities, conditions for registration, settlement of proceedings, and other matters that may be specified by regulations. The rules and regulations made under this Act must be laid before Parliament for a period of thirty days and can be modified or annulled by both Houses of Parliament. The Act is in addition to other laws in force and provides for the power to remove difficulties in implementing its provisions. Certain acts done under the principal Act are validated, and the Securities and Exchange Board of India Ordinance, 1992 is repealed.
